Problem:
Consider a complex function system represented by a linear operator \\( L \\) where \\( L(z) = Az + B \\), with \\( A \\) and \\( B \\) as matrices. We explore the role of a linear transformation represented by matrix \\( M \\) that modifies the input \\( z_0 \\) by the function \\( f(z) = Mz \\).

If \\( M \\) modifies an initial complex vector \\( z_0 \\) at time \\( t = 0 \\) and the system evolves according to \\( L \\) without further intervention, will the final state \\( z(T) \\), determined by \\( L \\) at time \\( T \\), be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was evolved under \\( L \\) alone?
Explanation: Modifying the initial state with \\( M \\) before applying the operator \\( L \\) changes the starting point, thus affecting the evolution of the system. Since \\( L(z) = Az + B \\), the impact of the matrix \\( M \\) influences how the vector sequence progresses, introducing a different trajectory than if \\( M \\) were not applied.

causal_map_integration: Applying the linear transformation M to the initial state z_0 results in z_1, which then evolves to z(T) under L. Alternatively, z_0 evolves directly to z(T) under L. These two paths do not necessarily yield the same final state z(T).
